bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê êh-pimohtêt wîsahkêcâhk , - nohtêhkatêw mâka mîna , - êh-pimohtêt , kâ-wâpamât sîsîpah , êkwah niskah mihcêt , sîsîpah . Once upon a time, as Wisahketchahk was tramping along as usual he was hungry as he was tramping along, he saw some ducks and many geese, ducks.

êkosi ômisi itêyihtam :
tânisi k-êsi-nipahakik ? itêyihtam . Then this was what he thought: “How shall I kill them?” he thought.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk sâkahikanis , êkotah sisonê nipîhk kâ-wâpahtahk asisiyah . Presently he saw a little lake, and by the water's edge some weeds.
otinam , êh-titipinahk . He took them and rolled them up.
mistahih tahkopitam , êh-nayahtahk , ê-sipwêhtêt . He tied up a great bundle of them, took it on his back, and went off.
sîsîpah itah k-âyâyit , êkotah cîkih êh-pimohtêt , kâ-wâpamikot sîsîpah . When he came walking close to where the ducks were, they caught sight of him.

ômis îtwêwak sîsîpak :
hâ , kistêsinaw ! itwêwak ; The ducks said, “Ho, our big brother!
kêkway kâ-nayahtahk ? êkosi itwêwak . What is that he's carrying on his back?” they said.
mahtih nika-kakwêcimâw , itwêw awa sîsîp . “Suppose I ask him,” said one duck.
êhag , itwêwak . “Yes, do,” they said.

seg.gloss: “Big brother, what is that you're carrying on your back?”

p.seg: âhci pikoh pimohtêw ; tâpiskôc êkâh êh-pêhtawât , âhci pikoh pimohtêw . He kept right on walking; just as if he had not heard, he kept on walking.

âsay mînah sîsîp omis îtêw :
nistêsê , kîkway kâ-nayahtaman ? Again the duck asked him, “Big brother, what is it you're carrying on your back?”
êkoyikohk nîpawiw wîsahkêcâhk . Only then did Wisahketchahk stand still.

mâh , itwêw ,
kîkway kâ-nayahtaman ? “Say,” it said, “what is it you're carrying?”
wâh , pasakwâpisimôwinah ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk . “Why, Shut-Eye Dances!” said Wisahketchahk.
kêkway pasakwâpisimôwin ? itwêw sîsîp . “What is a Shut-Eye Dance?” said the duck.

wîsahkêcâhk ômis îtwêw :
nîminânah , itêw . Wisahketchahk spoke thus: “A saltatory rite,” he told the other. LB on {nîminânah}: Unusual word.

nîmihinân , itwêw sîsîp ;
nka-pasakwâpisimonân ! “Do you give us a dance,” said the duck; “Let us dance the Shut-Eye Dance!”
hay hay ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk ; “Splendid!” cried Wisahketchahk;

seg.gloss: “Oh, it is fine that you have taken pity on me, little brothers!

p.seg: nam âwiyak ntâpwêhtâkoh , tê-nîmihitocik , kayâs ê-kîh-asotamân ta-nîmihitôwinihkêyân , itwêw wîsahkêcâhk ; No one has given heed to me until now, and danced, when long ago I had pledged myself to give a ritual dance,” said Wisahketchahk;

seg.gloss: “So then, come ashore.”

p.seg: ta-sipwêhtêwak êkwah sîsîpak mîna niskak . Off went the ducks and geese.
kahkiyaw itohtêwak . All of them came.

omis îtwêw wîsahkêcâhk :
maci-kakêpâtisak , ninohtêhkatêwa ! Thus spoke Wisahketchahk: “Hopeless ninnies, I've been starving!
mistahi nika-mîcison ! itêyihtam wîsahkêcâhk . I shall have a big meal!” thought Wisahketchahk.
êh-apit , êkotah takohtêyiwah . They came to where he sat.
âh , âstamitik , nisîmitik ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk . “Ha, come here, little brothers!” said Wisahketchahk.
êkwah ê-sipwêhtêt , ê-sakâyik êh-itohtêt , mihtah itah êh-mihcâniyikih , êkotah takohtêw . Setting out and making for a clump of trees, he came to where there was plenty of wood for a fire.
hâ , nisîmitik , otinamok mihtah , itwêw . “Ha, little brothers, take up some faggots,” he said.
tâpwê otinamwak mihcêt , êkwah ê-osihtâcik wîkiwâw , êkotah êh-apahkwêcik ôhô asisiyah . Accordingly they took up a plenty and built themselves a lodge, which they thatched with those weeds.
apisâsiniyiw iskwâhtêmis . The little doorway was very small.
hâ , êkwah , nisîmitik , pîhtokêk , itwêw ; “Ha, now, little brothers, come inside,” he said;
nîkân ta-pîhtokêwak niskak êkwah kâ-misikiticik sîsîpak , itwêw ; “First the geese and the big ducks will come in,” he said;
cikêmâ êyôkonik êh-okimâwicik , itwêw . “Especially those who are chiefs,” he said.
wêskwâhtêmihk êkosi ômisi itapiyiwah , êyakonik niskak . Accordingly these, the geese, sat like this, at the far end, facing the door.
nêtê iskwahtêmihk , êyakonik êh-apisîsisicik êkotah apiwak . Over at the other end, by the door sat the little fellows.

êkwah kipaham om iskwâhtêm awa wîsahkêcâhk ,
êkâh ka-wayawîcik , êh-itêyihtahk . Then that Wisahketchahk blocked up the doorway, thinking “So that they can't get out.”
êkwah mâtôw wîsahkêcâhk . Then Wisahketchahk wept.

seg.gloss: “Little brothers, I thank you for having built this lodge.

p.seg: êk âwiyak êh-kitimâkinawit , kiyawâw kâ-kitimâkinawiyêk , itwêw , êh-mâtot . When no one took pity on me, it was you who pitied me,” he spoke, weeping.
êkosi pôni-mâtôw . Then he ceased weeping.

ômisî itwêw wîsahkêcâhk :
hâw , nisîmitik , ôtah tâwayihk nika-nîpawin ; nika-nikamon . Thus spoke Wisahketchahk: “Now, little brothers, here in the centre I shall stand; I shall sing.

seg.gloss: When I sing, you will dance; [sic] you will close your eyes.
Not until I cease singing will you open your eyes.

seg.q:
kîspin manitôw nipêcimâw ,
hweh hweh hweh ! nik-êtwân ;
seg.gloss: When I summon the spirit-power, I shall say, ‘Hwe, hwe, hwe!’

seg.q: êkotah sôhkih ka-nîmihitonâwâw , pêhtawiyêkoh , êkosi itwêyânih .
seg.gloss: then you will dance with all your might, when you hear me call thus.

p.seg: âhag , itwêwak . “Very well,” they answered.

êkwah mistik tahkonam wîsahkêcâhk , nîpiyah ê-kayâsayiwiyikih êh-takopitêyikih , ômisi êy-isiwêpinahk , ê-sêwêpayiyikih , tâpiskôc sasawihyâkan , ôhi nîpiyah . Then Wisahketchahk took hold of a branch that had old leaves on it which rustled when he swung it, like this, just like a bell, those leaves.
êkosi êkwah nikamôw . Thereupon he began singing.

ômis îtwêw :
pasakwâpisimôwinah nipêciwitân ! êkos îtwêw , êh-nikamot . These were his words: “Shut-Eye Dances I bring here!” were the words of his song.

êkwah ôhi kahkiyaw êh-pasakwâpicik , êh-nîmihitocik , kîtahtawê ,
hweh hweh ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk , êh-otinât ê-misikitiyit niskah , êh-kîskikwêpitât . Then, when they all had closed their eyes and were dancing, presently, “Hwe, hwe!” went Wisahketchahk, taking hold of a big goose and wringing its neck.

êkos ê-ati-wâsakâmêt , tahk êh-nikamot , êh-ati-kîskikwêpitât niskah ôhi mîna sîsîpah kâ-misikitiyit . In this way he kept on circling round, singing all the while, and, as he went, wringing the necks of the geese and of the big ducks.

nêtêh skwâhtêmihk êh-nîmihitot sihkihp , êwakoh êh-pêhtahk kêkway , êh-napatêh-tôhkâpit , êh-nîmihitot , kâ-wâpamât wîsahkêcâhkwah êh-ati-nipahâyit . Over yonder by the door danced Hell-Diver, and when he heard something or other, and opened one eye as he danced, there he saw Wisahketchahk killing one after another.

îyahâ ! itwêw ,
mâka mînah kimêscihikonaw wîsahkêcâhk ! itwêw . “Yah!” he cried, “It's the same old story, Wisahketchahk is killing us off!”

êh-tôhkâpicik kotakak , omis îtwêw wîsahkêcâhk :
kêkway ôma itah kê-pêtâyân nîmihitôwin , kâkêpâtisicik ? When the others opened their eyes, Wisahketchahk said, “What sort of a dance would I be bringing you blockheads? LB on {kâkêpâtisicik}: The ending of the vocative plural is, of course, {-itik}. The sound {c} for {t} appears in diminutives (among the younger generation of speakers, almost universally); less often in other words formed with suffixes containing {s} (as in the present instance); and occasionally in other words, probably always with a diminutive touch.
ninôhtêhkatâh ! itêw ôhi sîsîpah . I was hungry, that's all!” he said to those ducks.
wayawîyâmowak kotakak , êh-tapasîcik . They fled out of doors, the others, trying to get away.

êkosi wayawîw wîsahkêcâhk , êh-pâhpit , êh-miywêyihtahk ,
mistahi nika-mîcison , êh-itêyihtahk . Thereupon Wisahketchahk went out of the lodge, laughing and rejoicing, thinking, “I shall eat a plenty.”

êkosi pîkonam oma wîkih , ôhi mihtah êh-otinahk , êh-kotawêt , ôhih ê-wih-nawacît nîpin-âyah . So then he tore up that lodge of his, taking the faggots and building a fire to roast those summer creatures.
êkosi êh-nawacît , kahkiyaw nawacîw . He roasted them whole.
êkosi ôsâm mistah êh-pônahk , âpwêsiw . Having made too big a fire, he began to feel hot.
êkoyikohk ta-kîsisôwak niniskimak , êh-itêyihtahk . by that time my geese will be done.”

tâpwâh wâhyawês êh-itohtêt , kâ-wâpamât mahkêsîsah ê-wîsakêyihtamiyit oskâtiyiw , êh-watiskâyit , êkâ êh-kih-pimohtêyit , ê-wîh-tapasîhikot . And so when he had walked a little ways, there he saw Fox, who had a pain in his leg, and was limping and could not walk properly, as he tried to run away from him.
cêskwa , nisîm ! itêw . “Wait a moment, little brother!” he called to him.

namoya ! itêw ;
ê-wih-âcimostâtân . “No! he told him; “It is only that I want to tell you some news.

seg.q: îh oma kiwâpahtên cî mistahi kâ-pikihtêk ?
seg.gloss: Do you see all the smoke rising over here?”

p.seg: êhag , itik . “Yes,” said the other to him.
êkotah mihcêt ninipahâwak niskak mîna sîsîpak , êkotah êh-nawaciyân , êh-itât ; “Over there I have killed a lot of geese and ducks, and there I am roasting them,” he told him;

seg.gloss: “But first let us race.
Let us run around that hill not far from here.”

p.seg: hâh , namoya ! kiwâpamin êkâh êh-kîh-pimohtêyân , ê-wîsakêyihtamân niskât , itwêw mahkêsîs . “Oh dear, no! You see I can't walk, with my sore leg,” said Fox.

omis îtwêw wîsahkêcâhk :
asiniyak niskâtihk nika-tahkopitâwak , itwêw . Wisahketchahk spoke thus: “I shall tie stones to my leg,” he said.
êhag , itwêw mahkêsîs . “Very well,” said Fox.
asiniyah otinêw wîsahkêcâhk , êh-tahkopitât oskâtihk . Wisahketchahk took some stones and tied them to his leg.

seg.gloss: “There, little brother, come on!”

p.seg: êkwah sipwêpahtâwak . So they set off at a run.
nakatêw mahkêsîsah wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk left Fox behind.

seg.q: hêy , omîhkawikîh awa mahkêsîs , kâ-kitimâkaskâtak nisîm !
seg.gloss: “Hey, I thought this Fox was a runner, this poor little brother of mine whom I am leaving so far behind!

p.seg: itâp âtiht nik-âsamâw , êyikohk ta-takopahtâcih , itwêw wîsahkêcâhk . I shall give the poor fellow a few of then when he arrives from his run,” said Wisahketchahk.

mayaw êh-âkawêwêt wîsahkêcâhk , kîwêpayiw awa mahkêsîs , namoya ê-wîsakêyihtahk oskât , ôma kâ-pikihtêyik êy-ispayit . As soon as Wisahketchahk was out of sight behind the hill, that Fox turned back, and his leg was not sore at all, as he made for the rising smoke.
êh-takohtêt , niskah sîsîpah mîna kâ-wâpamât êh-kîsisoyit . When he got there, there he saw the geese and ducks a-roasting.
otinêw , êkwah êh-mîcisot , wîsahkêcâhkwah êh-kimotamawât onawacîwiniyiwa . He took them and ate, robbing Wisahketchahk of his roasts.
kitamwêw kahkiyaw . He ate them all up.

ositiyiwah pikoh ôhi niskah êkwah sîsîpah , êkonih piko iskotêhk astâw ,
ta-wâpahtahk wîsahkêcâhk , êh-itêyihtah . Only the feet of those geese and ducks, only those did he put into the embers, thinking, “Let Wisahketchahk see them.”

êkosi tapasîw ,
nka-kisiwâhâw , êh-itêyimât wîsahkêcâhkwah . Then he made for safety, thinking of Wisahketchahk, “He will be angry at me.”
êkwah wîsahkêcâhk iyikohk êh-takohtêt mistah âpwêsiw ; ayisk mistahi pimipahtâw . Then, when Wisahketchahk arrived, he was very hot; for he had had quite a run.
hêy , âstêpwêsiyânih nika-mîcison , êh-itêyihtah , “Hah, when I am no longer hot, I shall eat,” he thought;

itâp âtiht nk-âsamâw nisîm , itêw mahkêsîsah ,
iyikohk takohtêcih , itêyihtam . “I shall give my little brother a few, too,” he said of Fox, “when he gets here,” he thought.
namoya kiskêyihtam âsay êh-kitamwâyit oniskimah . He did not know that the other had already eaten his geese.
êkosi êkwan otinam ôm ôsitiyiw . So now he took one of those feet.
nama kêkway niskah . There was not any goose.
hê hê hêy , nôsâmih-mêstihkaswâw ! itwêw . “Oho, I have overcooked him!” he said.
piyis kahkiyaw otinêw ; kahkiyaw nama kêkway ; ositiyiwah piko . At last he took them all out; ever one was gone; only the feet were there.

seg.q: hê hê hêy , mâka mîn êcik ânih êh-wayêsihit mahêsihit mahkêsîs , kâ-kitamwât niniskimah !
seg.gloss: “Oho, it's surely Fox has been fooling me again, eating up my geese!
seg.note: CHECK: probable speaker error, possibly blend of surrounding words

p.seg: êkos êcik ânih kê-nôhtêhkatêyân ! itwêw ; And so I am to stay hungry!” he cried;

seg.gloss: “Ho, you have got me angry, Fox!
The earth will not be big enough for you to escape.
It was I created the earth;
I will find you;

p.seg: miskâtânih kâ-kitamwacik niniskimak ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk , êh-sipwêhtêt , êh-ntonawât mahkêsîsah . and when I find you, who ate up my geese!” cried Wisahketchahk, as he went off to look for Fox.

namoya wâhyaw êh-ihtât , kâ-wâpamât , êh-na-nipâyit , mitonih êh-mistatayêyit ; ayisk kîh-kîspoyiwah . He had not gone far, when he saw him taking a nap, his belly all big; for he had eaten a hearty fill.
asiniyah otinêw , ê-wîh-pakamahwât . He took up a stone, to strike him.
nik-ôtastotinih awa mahkêsîsiwayân ! itwêw ; “I might as well have a cap of his fox-pelt!” he said;
kiyâm nka-pasisamawâw , ta-nipahâpasot ôm ôhci paskâpahtêw , itwêw . “I had better make a fire round him so that he chokes in the smoke,” he said.
na-nitohtâk , ôm êh-itât . The other was listening to what he said about him.
êkosi kotawêw , wâsakâm ê-saskahahk maskosiyah . So then he made a fire, setting fire the grass round about.
êkwah êh-kwâhkotêyik , waniskâw awa mahkêsîs . When the blaze came, Fox got up.
mistahi kaskâpâsôw . The smoke was getting too thick for him.

heg , wîsahkêcâhk omis îtwêw ;
hiheg , mahti mînah kitamok niniskimak ! itêw . “Ha,” said Wisahketchahk; “Haha, just you eat up my geese again!” he said to him.
kontah wâskâpayihôw awa mahkêsîs , êh-kaskâpahtêyik mistahi . Fox dashed about in a circle, this way and that, as the smoke grew denser.
piyisk namoya wâpamêw wîsahkâcâhk . At last Wisahketchahk could see him no more.
kwaskwêpayihôw awa mahkêsîs , iskotêw oma êh-pâsici-kwaskohtit , êh-tapasît . Up leaped Fox, jumping across the flame, and making for safety.
namoya wâpamêw wîsahkêcâhk , êh-tapasiyit . Wisahketchahk did not see how he ran away.
piyis misiwê pasitêyiw , êkotah êh-wâskâhtêt wîsahkêcâhk . At last there was a big fire, and Wisahketchahk kept walking round it.
tâpwê nikitimahâw , êh-nipahîhkaswak mahkêsîs , itwêw wîsahkêcâhk ; “I have surely put an end to Fox; burning him to death,” said Wisahketchahk;

kâ-wâpahtahk pihkoh êh-astêyik , mostoso-mêy itah êh-kiy-astêyik ,
tâpwê nikitimâkîhkaswâw ! êh-itwêt ; and when he saw the ashes lying, where there had been buffalo-dung, “Surely I have burned him to a sorry end!” said he;
mahtih k-êskohkasot , nka-môwâw , iskohkasocih , êh-itêyihtah ; “I shall eat what is left of him, if there is any of him left from the fire,” he thought;

oma pihkoh ê-wîh-otinahk ,
kâ-kîsisot iskotêw ês ômah êwako mahkêsîs , êh-iytêyihtah , êh-cîsihot . and he was going to take up the ashes there, thinking, “And this must be Fox, burned up in this fire,” as he deceived himself.
êkoyikohk namoya kiskêyihtam ê-kîh-tapasiyit . Even now he did not know that the other had got away.
êkosi êkoyikohk êwako âtayôhkêwin . And so this is the end of this sacred story.

êh-tah-tahkiskawât sihkihpah ,
hâw , ôtêh nîkân ayîsiyiniw kit-ôhpikiw ; When he kicked Hell-Diver, “Now then, ahead in future time mortal man will grow up; LB: THis paragraph was added in answer to a leading question. “I did not tell you that part,” he explained. This is a characteristic of our informant. Notice that even now he does not explain the diver duck's red eyes.

seg.gloss: he will see here on you where I have kicked your rump crooked.
‘Hell-Diver,’ they will call you.
You will not be handsome;

p.seg: osâm kikisiwâhin êh-wîhtaman , êh-tôhkâpiyan , itêw . too much have you angered me by telling this and by opening your eyes,” he told him.
êkosi êyôkô . So much for this.
